image.altText: An illustration of Islamic State iconography superimposed over a browser window containing an image of Rick Astley.

items.synopsis: Defeating Islamic State militants required disabling their significant cyber capabilities — and pop star Rick Astley unwittingly played a hand in doing so.

title.children: In the heat of battle, IS militants' phones were hijacked thanks to Australians inspired by Rick Astley

image.altText: A close-up of brown Aspen Methadone Syrup bottles

items.synopsis: More than a dozen private opioid treatment services in Queensland and New South Wales are at risk of closure because of changes announced in last month's federal budget, say clinic operators.

title.children: Warning of 'imminent disaster' as government changes may leave people addicted to opioids with nowhere to turn

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann speaks to 7NEWS Spotlight in an interview.

items.synopsis: Former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann says he may still sue Brittany Higgins personally for defamation, in his first television interview since she accused him of raping her at Parliament House in 2019.

title.children: '50pc of the country thinks I'm a rapist': Bruce Lehrmann says he may sue Brittany Higgins over allegation he denies

image.altText: A smiling teenager wearing a backwards cap and a pink singlet petting wildlife.

items.synopsis: The homicide investigation into the suspected murder of Linden Malayta, an Indigenous teenager missing for more than four years, has progressed with detectives alleging a firearm led to his death.

title.children: Queensland Police allege missing Indigenous teen Linden Malayta was shot

image.altText: Nine teenagers wearing matching blue jeans and white tshirt and sneakers pose for a photo in front of their school building

items.synopsis: Despite their school being struck by a missile, those who remain of the class of 2023 in Kharkiv aren't letting a war rob them of their graduation celebrations.

title.children: The Kharkiv class of 2023 may be few in number, but it holds big hopes for the future

image.altText: Orange e-scooter left parked on pathway with pedestrians walking in the background at South Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Following new rules introduced by the Queensland government in November, personal mobility device riders have been fined for a range of offences including speeding more than 30kph over the limit.

title.children: E-scooter riders hit with nearly 1,000 fines in first three months of new laws

image.altText: Jamie and Mick at a table, both have one hand on braille protoype, both smiling.

items.synopsis: Mick and Jamie have been mates for almost three decades and have worked on a project with one goal in mind — to ensure everyone can use a computer.

title.children: Mick and Jamie created software that could have made them rich. This is why they don't want a cent

image.altText: A man surrounded by cameras.

items.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann's interview on 7NEWS Spotlight was largely a retelling of the defence arguments in his trial but, for many Australians, it was the first time hearing his version of events, in his own words.

title.children: Last night was the first time many Australians heard Bruce Lehrmann speak, and it was mostly a summary of his defence

image.altText: An aerial view of coal extracted from the Narrabri mine, with a landscape of lakes and mountains behind it.

items.synopsis: An ABC analysis uncovers several examples of project approval being granted to coalmines based on environmental assessments that contained significant underestimates of their greenhouse gas pollution.

title.children: This coalmine is polluting three times as much as expected. And that's not unusual

image.altText: a huge crocodile in a small pond

items.synopsis: The giant animal's birthday will be celebrated at its home on Green Island in the Great Barrier Reef.

title.children: Cassius is the largest saltwater crocodile in captivity in the world. He might also be one of the oldest on Earth

image.altText: Jenny Odell, with shoulder-length black hair and black shirt, sits before blurred greenery behind her, smiling widely.

items.synopsis: Hyper-efficiency, or squeezing the most from every moment of the day, won't make time seem more expansive, argues author Jenny Odell. Here's what she says will.

title.children: Waking at 4am to exercise, 'crushing' your day and other habits that may be making you less happy

image.altText: man sitting on bench in front of ocean

items.synopsis: The Gold Coast faces "unique" challenges for mental health services, as psychologists warn they cannot meet demand unless training pathways are reformed and Medicare rebates are increased.

title.children: Psychologists call for rebate reform as cost of living crisis increases demand on services

image.altText: Miyu Kato

items.synopsis: A doubles team is sent packing from the French Open after a controversial disqualification, while Novak Djokovic breaks a Rafael Nadal record.

title.children: 'Crying for like 15 minutes': Doubles team bounced from French Open after ball kid hit

image.altText: Aunty Cheryl has short hair, glasses and is wearing a blue puffer jacket next to statue of her mother holding a washing basket

items.synopsis: More than 100 First Nations people lived on Jackson's Track east of Melbourne from the 1940s to the 1960s. Three Kurnai women protected the women from violence and prevented children from being taken from their families.

title.children: How three matriarchs protected women and children at Jackson's Track

image.altText: A qantas plane taking off into a clear blue sky with a city skyline at the bottom in the distance

items.synopsis: The Australian consumer watchdog has taken aim at the airline industry, saying a lack of competition is driving up prices and resulting in poorer service, while the ASX is set to rise after a US debt deal was reached. Follow live.

title.children: ACCC says lack of competition is causing airfares to soar, ASX to jump as US debt deal secured

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200 futures: +1% to 7,229 points Australian dollar: -0.15% at 66.01 US cents S & P 500 (Friday): +1.5% to 4,282 points Nasdaq (Friday): +1% to 13,240 points FTSE (Friday): +1.6% to 7,607 points EuroStoxx (Friday): +1.5% to 4323 points Spot gold: +0.1% to $US1,949/ounce Brent crude: +0.1% to $US75.64/barrel Iron ore (Friday): -$106.33/tonne Bitcoin: +0.6% to $AU41,424 Live updates on the major ASX indices:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 8.30am AEST

children.content: Live updates on the major ASX indices:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The consumer watchdog warns a lack of competition is pushing up airfares and leading to poorer service. The ACCC says Qantas and Virgin fly more than 90 per cent of domestic passengers — creating one of the most concentrated industries in the country. It wants Sydney Airport — as the country's busiest — to open up more slots to emerging carriers Rex and Bonza. It's also called on the federal government to take a closer look at customer service — with cancellations and delays still significantly above average.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sky-high airfares and poor service due to a lack of airline competition, ACCC says

children.content: The consumer watchdog warns a lack of competition is pushing up airfares and leading to poorer service.
The ACCC says Qantas and Virgin fly more than 90 per cent of domestic passengers — creating one of the most concentrated industries in the country.
It wants Sydney Airport — as the country's busiest — to open up more slots to emerging carriers Rex and Bonza.
It's also called on the federal government to take a closer look at customer service — with cancellations and delays still significantly above average.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team with you through the morning. The key local index, the ASX 200 is set to jump - something predicted in trade on the futures market, which sees it it up 76 points or 1.06% to 7,229.0. But that's just a guess. We're ahead of other key indicies - it's Sunday evening in New York, very late Sunday evening in London - so we get to lead a bit. Trading in stocks begins at 10AM (for the Eastern states) so we'll find out more! Get set and we'll have more for you soon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX trade to begin, as New York and London slumber

children.content: Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team with you through the morning.
The key local index, the ASX 200 is set to jump - something predicted in trade on the futures market, which sees it it up 76 points or 1.06% to 7,229.0.
But that's just a guess. We're ahead of other key indicies - it's Sunday evening in New York, very late Sunday evening in London - so we get to lead a bit.
Trading in stocks begins at 10AM (for the Eastern states) so we'll find out more!
Get set and we'll have more for you soon.

image.altText: Gary leans over Monic who is sitting in a hospital chair holding their baby

items.synopsis: Amid a cost-of-living crisis, international students in Australia will soon be forced to cut their working hours as previous rules put on hold to address labour shortages are reintroduced.

title.children: International students given grace period on working hours argue for the change to stay

image.altText: A man standing in a kitchen making a sandwich.

items.synopsis: Regional and rural people who are forced to travel to major centres for medical treatment say the travel subsidy scheme is not keeping up with the cost of living.

title.children: Patients facing choice of food or care as they battle costs of long-distance medical treatment

image.altText: Alexei Navalny looks stoic, with supporters with flags behind him

items.synopsis: Police in Russia have arrested more than 100 people who had taken to the streets to mark the 47th birthday of jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny, a protest-monitoring group says.

title.children: Supporters of Russian opposition leader arrested during demonstrations

image.altText: Natalie Barr and Matt Shirvington smiling together

items.synopsis: The former sprinter will be co-anchoring the channel 7's breakfast news program after Koch leaves the show he hosted for more than 20 years.

title.children: Former Olympian Matt Shirvington to replace David Koch on Sunrise

image.altText: a building with Selwyn Snow Resort written on it and it's covered in snow

items.synopsis: Businesses in the Snowy Mountains are celebrating the return of Selwyn Snow Resort, reopening its doors next weekend for the first time since the Black Summer bushfires.

title.children: Kosciuszko ski resort reopens to guests, three years after Black Summer bushfires

image.altText: A lizard looking straight at the camera up and close

items.synopsis: A rise in the illegal trade of exotic Australian animals has made a remote Queensland outpost an unlikely front line in the fight against international smugglers.

title.children: Outback lizards on hit list for international animal traffickers

image.altText: A close-up of a man aboard the Sundance Sail Darwin catamaran.

items.synopsis: This was supposed to be the year tourism across the Northern Territory bounced back, but weeks into what should be the peak of the season, David Woodrow is cutting his Darwin Harbour sunset cruises.

title.children: It's nearing the peak of the tourist season in the Top End, so why have visitor numbers dwindled?

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith looks at the camera outside a court building

items.synopsis: Last week's abridged version of Justice Anthony Besanko's judgement is set to be fleshed out when his full reasons are published today.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith will find out today how judge reached decision in defamation trial

image.altText: Aunty McRose Elu standing infront of tropical greenery with a bright shirt on wearing glasses and looking serious

items.synopsis: Aunty McRose Elu has been watching her ancestral lands slowly disappear beneath her feet for decades. The Saibai elder fears rising sea levels and increasingly severe weather events could mean her homeland is uninhabitable within 30 years.

title.children: 'Leave their bones behind': Elders fear losing gravesites in Torres Strait as climate change court fight continues

image.altText: A camel leans in to the camera

items.synopsis: Every hero has a villain, and for many in the outback it is a thorny shrub called prickly acacia.

title.children: Paul loves his camels, and now thanks to their weed-eating superpowers, so do farmers

image.altText: A man of colour in a blue suit and white shirt stands and points at a computer screen where a young Asian woman is working.

items.synopsis: With productivity falling in Australia and AI developments advancing, could the technology be the answer to boosting output, or will it cause more job losses?

title.children: Amit's firm has modelled the jobs most likely to be affected by AI. The top 10 might surprise you

image.altText: Three children, a mother and a child walking together

items.synopsis: Everyone on Jessica's side of her family has been diagnosed with Huntington's disease. She is watching her mother slowly die, and has the condition herself.

title.children: 'I'm watching her die slowly': What it's like having the rare genetic condition Huntington's disease

image.altText: A person's blurred shoulder as they walk past a PWC logo.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant PwC is embroiled in a scandal of its own doing, having used confidential government information to benefit its bottom line. Here's how it happened, and what consequences the firm is facing.

title.children: At least 53 people knew about the PwC tax leak — so why don't we know who they are?

image.altText: A worker welds as he installs bore-pile devices at a steel fabrication of rebar cages .

items.synopsis: New research finds China has surrendered its position as the largest single provider of development finance in South-East Asia in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: China overtaken as largest provider of development money in South-East Asia

image.altText: Passengers gather around a bus, flipped on its side, in a ditch, after a crash at night off a highway.

items.synopsis: An Australian woman who was involved in a bus crash in Italy which reportedly claimed one life, says the company that owned the vehicle offered passengers a meal voucher "for the inconvenience".

title.children: Australian involved in fatal Italian bus crash says company offered $16 meal voucher

image.altText: A landfill site with a large white "membrane" over the top.

items.synopsis: The closure of north Queensland's largest landfill has sparked a massive rehabilitation operation that will result in the site being "capped" to look like a natural hill. But what is the true cost of burying the region’s waste?

title.children: What happens when a landfill reaches its limits?

image.altText: An old coloured photo of two smiling men in the outback, blue sky, red earth, stand next to ta film camera. Both w

items.synopsis: From gun-slinging stand-offs to scorched testicles, the surviving half of the Leyland Brothers has plenty of stories left to tell.

title.children: Leyland Brothers put life and loins on the line for adventure, but the surviving half isn't giving up yet
